parameters.source_text:
Case 17-3
Canterbury v. Spence and the Reasonable-Person
Consent Standard
Jerry Canterbury, age 19, was a clerk typist for the Federal Bureau of Inves-
tigation. He suffered severe back pain for which, in December of 1958, he
consulted two general practitioners. When the medication they prescribed
did not resolve his problems, he consulted a neurosurgeon, Dr. William
Spence. When x-rays did not reveal the problem, he proposed a myelogram
during which a dye would be injected into the spinal column to help visual-
ize any abnormality.
Based on the myelogram, a rupured disk was suspected, and, in February
of 1959, a laminectomy was performed to which his mother consented
(apparently after the operation was over) because Canterbury was a minor.
After the procedure, Dr. Spence told him to stay in bed while voiding, but
the orders were changed (it is unclear by whom), indicating he should get
out of bed to urinate. Hospital personnel gave him a receptacle in which
to void and left him unattended. Canterbury slipped off the side of the bed
and fell to the floor. Later that day he complained of difficulty breathing
and inability to move his legs. Dr. Spence recommended a second opera-
tion to correct the problem, but Canterbury was left incontinent and with
paralysis of his bowels and hobbled about on crutches. In June of 1962 he
had to resign from the FBI for health reasons.
In March of 1963 Canterbury filed suit in the United States District Court
against Dr. Spence and the Washington Hospital Center claiming negligence
in performing the operation and failure to inform him of the risks. After a di-
rected verdict in favor of the doctor and hospital, Canterbury appealed to the
federal Court of Appeals. In addressing the consent issues, that court noted
that many jurisdictions rely on “the custom of physicians practicing in the
community to make the particular disclosure to the patient.” This court, how-
ever, adopted a different standard. After rejecting the notion that there must
be “full” disclosure, the court held that the physician must disclose every-
thing that the patient would need to know in making the decision for the
therapy, that is, everything that is “material to the decision.” This standard
is independent of the practice of physicians in the community. It is what
has come to be called “the reasonable-man” or later “the personable-person”
standard. The case was then sent back to the lower court to determine
whether those pieces of information had been adequately disclosed.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old with months of severe low back pain now has leg numbness. Imaging is inconclusive. The neurosurgeon recommends a myelogram today and, if it suggests a herniated disk, a laminectomy tomorrow morning. The patient is exhausted, in pain, and says he wants “whatever gets me back to work fast.” He also becomes visibly panicked when complications are mentioned and asks the surgeon not to “go through every scary possibility.” The surgeon knows the procedures are routine but can rarely lead to permanent neurologic injury, even with proper technique. A longer consent discussion will likely delay the case and may lead the patient to refuse any invasive testing. Hospital policy and state law permit either a detailed risk discussion or a patient-directed, limited disclosure if clearly documented. You must decide how to proceed with consent now.
data.choice_1: Give a full material-risk consent discussion before proceeding.
data.choice_2: Provide a limited, patient-directed consent discussion and proceed as planned.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that implies one option is clinically preferable. Specifically, revise “The surgeon knows the procedures are routine” to a neutral framing (e.g., “The procedures are commonly performed but carry rare serious risks”). Avoid implying that a longer consent “will likely” delay/refusal as a predictable clinical outcome; rephrase to “could delay” and “might increase the chance the patient declines.” Consider adding a brief line that either approach can be compatible with safe care when appropriately documented, so the tension stays ethical rather than outcome-driven.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or clarify extraneous/unclear clinical elements that don’t affect the ethical choice and add only what’s needed to ground consent. Examples: specify why the myelogram must be done today (e.g., OR slot and radiology availability) and why MRI/CT are inconclusive (one clause). Remove “months of severe low back pain” unless it directly affects urgency; you can keep “progressive pain and new neurologic symptoms.” Consider removing “whatever gets me back to work fast” unless you explicitly link it to his preference for speed over discussion; otherwise keep as a single line about urgency/financial pressure.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Tighten medical realism: jumping from inconclusive imaging to same-day myelogram and next-day laminectomy is possible but needs justification. Add a line such as: “MRI is limited by metal artifact/claustrophobia/non-diagnostic; CT suggests possible compressive lesion; radiology can perform myelography today and an OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if findings correlate.” Also consider whether ‘laminectomy’ vs ‘microdiscectomy’ is the intended procedure; if you keep laminectomy, specify it’s for suspected large herniation/stenosis and that surgery is elective but time-sensitive due to worsening neurologic symptoms.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the case leans toward limited disclosure by stating a fuller discussion will ‘likely’ delay care and lead refusal, and by calling the procedure ‘routine.’ To make both options genuinely defensible, add countervailing costs to limited disclosure (e.g., risk the patient later feels misled, potential erosion of trust, possibility he would have chosen differently if he knew about neurologic injury). Also add costs to full disclosure beyond delay (e.g., patient’s acute panic may impair comprehension; excessive detail could be non-beneficial in this moment). Rephrase so neither path is framed as the safer/standard one; instead, both are reasonable within policy with different ethical downsides.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical conflict unavoidable and not primarily about communication style by specifying that the patient either (a) explicitly refuses to hear specific risks (e.g., paralysis, CSF leak, infection) and requests to proceed today, or (b) will only proceed if not told the risks. Also clarify the surgeon’s concern: without disclosing paralysis risk, the surgeon worries the consent may be insufficient for an elective myelogram/laminectomy; with full disclosure, the surgeon expects acute distress leading to refusal and ongoing neurologic compromise. Remove/soften the line that the procedures are 'routine' (it biases toward proceeding) and ensure each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another (e.g., full disclosure protects informed choice but risks immediate harm from delay; limited disclosure respects the patient’s request and expedites care but risks undermining informed authorization and later moral injury/betrayal).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize by tightening the binary to a concrete action threshold: (1) disclose and document specific serious risks despite the patient’s request not to hear them; (2) accept the patient’s refusal of risk details and document that choice, disclosing only the most common/non-serious risks. Specify what 'limited' means and what 'full' must include (at least the small but devastating neurologic injury risk). Otherwise small wording shifts (e.g., 'rare' vs 'small' risk) can flip which option seems ethically acceptable.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify whether the patient has decision-making capacity (pain, exhaustion, panic) and whether anxiety is so severe it impairs understanding. State that the patient can repeat back the purpose/alternatives but becomes distressed by enumerating risks. Without this, graders may disagree whether the issue is autonomy vs nonmaleficence or capacity/informed consent adequacy. Also clarify that no surrogate is available and the decision must be made today due to scheduling/neurologic symptoms.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the 'free lunch' feel favoring limited disclosure by adding credible downsides to proceeding with limited consent: potential later regret/complaint, moral injury to clinician, and that paralysis risk—while uncommon—is catastrophic and arguably material. Balance the other side by making delay meaningfully risky (worsening neurologic deficit, loss of surgical window, prolonged suffering) so full disclosure is not obviously best. Avoid relying on 'policy/state law permits' as a trump card; instead state both approaches are legally permissible but professionally contested.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove wording that implicitly favors limited disclosure. For example, replace “procedures are routine” with “procedures are commonly performed,” and replace “A longer consent discussion will likely delay the case and may lead the patient to refuse” with a more neutral description of competing concerns (e.g., “A longer consent discussion could delay same-day testing and may increase the patient’s anxiety, but may improve informed decision-making”). Avoid quoting “scary possibility”; rephrase clinically (e.g., “requests a more limited discussion of risks”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the clinical plan and what decision must be made now. Specify whether the myelogram requires sedation or other time-limited logistics that make ‘today’ essential, and why imaging is inconclusive (e.g., MRI nondiagnostic/contraindicated). Tighten by removing redundant affective descriptors (“exhausted, in pain”) unless they relate to decisional capacity; if capacity is relevant, state it explicitly (e.g., “appears to have capacity despite distress”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices parallel, action-only, and ~10–15 words. For example: (1) “Conduct comprehensive informed consent covering material risks before myelogram today.” (2) “Use documented patient-requested limited disclosure consent and proceed with myelogram today.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that makes Choice 2 look like a way to avoid refusal/delay and Choice 1 look like the ‘safer/more proper’ option. Rewrite to give each choice distinct, symmetric ethical costs: e.g., explicitly note that a full material-risk discussion may exacerbate panic and undermine the patient’s expressed preference not to hear details (risking distress and loss of trust), while limited disclosure risks later feelings of betrayal and medico-legal/relational harm if a complication occurs. Also neutralize language like ‘procedures are routine’ which downplays risk and can make limited disclosure seem more acceptable; instead state they are commonly performed but carry rare, serious harms. Add a sentence that the patient appears to understand the general nature/purpose and is decisional, but his anxiety is escalating, to keep both approaches defensible.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a clear third option exists: pause/short delay to manage anxiety and revisit consent (analgesia/anxiolysis, involve family/advocate, use staged consent: consent for myelogram now, decide on surgery after results, or schedule a dedicated consent conversation later today). To force a true binary, explicitly rule out these intermediates: e.g., ‘Radiology has a single slot now; if missed, myelogram is delayed weeks, and the OR slot is released; no time for additional consults. Patient declines involving family and refuses sedation that would impair decision-making. The surgeon must either conduct a full material-risk review now or honor the patient’s request for limited disclosure and document it.’ Alternatively, change the binary to: (A) proceed today with myelogram under limited disclosure vs (B) do not proceed today and instead postpone invasive testing until a full consent discussion can occur.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: This scenario may be largely resolved by legal/professional standards: if state law and hospital policy explicitly permit ‘patient-directed limited disclosure,’ then Choice 2 is legally sanctioned; if they require ‘material risk’ disclosure, Choice 2 is noncompliant. Either way, guidelines may override the dilemma. Fix by clarifying that standards are ambiguous or conflicting: e.g., hospital policy requires material-risk disclosure for surgery but allows patient-directed limitation for diagnostic procedures; state case law is unsettled about how far patients can waive disclosure for high-severity risks; risk management advises either approach is defensible if capacity and documentation are clear. Also add that a neurologic-injury risk, while rare, might be considered ‘material’ by some standards, making the permissibility contested rather than settled.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that implies one option is clinically preferable. Specifically, revise “The surgeon knows the procedures are routine” to a neutral framing (e.g., “The procedures are commonly performed but carry rare serious risks”). Avoid implying that a longer consent “will likely” delay/refusal as a predictable clinical outcome; rephrase to “could delay” and “might increase the chance the patient declines.” Consider adding a brief line that either approach can be compatible with safe care when appropriately documented, so the tension stays ethical rather than outcome-driven.
key_information: Trim or clarify extraneous/unclear clinical elements that don’t affect the ethical choice and add only what’s needed to ground consent. Examples: specify why the myelogram must be done today (e.g., OR slot and radiology availability) and why MRI/CT are inconclusive (one clause). Remove “months of severe low back pain” unless it directly affects urgency; you can keep “progressive pain and new neurologic symptoms.” Consider removing “whatever gets me back to work fast” unless you explicitly link it to his preference for speed over discussion; otherwise keep as a single line about urgency/financial pressure.
clinical_plausibility: Tighten medical realism: jumping from inconclusive imaging to same-day myelogram and next-day laminectomy is possible but needs justification. Add a line such as: “MRI is limited by metal artifact/claustrophobia/non-diagnostic; CT suggests possible compressive lesion; radiology can perform myelography today and an OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if findings correlate.” Also consider whether ‘laminectomy’ vs ‘microdiscectomy’ is the intended procedure; if you keep laminectomy, specify it’s for suspected large herniation/stenosis and that surgery is elective but time-sensitive due to worsening neurologic symptoms.
non_triviality: As written, the case leans toward limited disclosure by stating a fuller discussion will ‘likely’ delay care and lead refusal, and by calling the procedure ‘routine.’ To make both options genuinely defensible, add countervailing costs to limited disclosure (e.g., risk the patient later feels misled, potential erosion of trust, possibility he would have chosen differently if he knew about neurologic injury). Also add costs to full disclosure beyond delay (e.g., patient’s acute panic may impair comprehension; excessive detail could be non-beneficial in this moment). Rephrase so neither path is framed as the safer/standard one; instead, both are reasonable within policy with different ethical downsides.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical conflict unavoidable and not primarily about communication style by specifying that the patient either (a) explicitly refuses to hear specific risks (e.g., paralysis, CSF leak, infection) and requests to proceed today, or (b) will only proceed if not told the risks. Also clarify the surgeon’s concern: without disclosing paralysis risk, the surgeon worries the consent may be insufficient for an elective myelogram/laminectomy; with full disclosure, the surgeon expects acute distress leading to refusal and ongoing neurologic compromise. Remove/soften the line that the procedures are 'routine' (it biases toward proceeding) and ensure each option clearly promotes one value while compromising another (e.g., full disclosure protects informed choice but risks immediate harm from delay; limited disclosure respects the patient’s request and expedites care but risks undermining informed authorization and later moral injury/betrayal).
directional_stability: Stabilize by tightening the binary to a concrete action threshold: (1) disclose and document specific serious risks despite the patient’s request not to hear them; (2) accept the patient’s refusal of risk details and document that choice, disclosing only the most common/non-serious risks. Specify what 'limited' means and what 'full' must include (at least the small but devastating neurologic injury risk). Otherwise small wording shifts (e.g., 'rare' vs 'small' risk) can flip which option seems ethically acceptable.
interpretive_consensus: Clarify whether the patient has decision-making capacity (pain, exhaustion, panic) and whether anxiety is so severe it impairs understanding. State that the patient can repeat back the purpose/alternatives but becomes distressed by enumerating risks. Without this, graders may disagree whether the issue is autonomy vs nonmaleficence or capacity/informed consent adequacy. Also clarify that no surrogate is available and the decision must be made today due to scheduling/neurologic symptoms.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the 'free lunch' feel favoring limited disclosure by adding credible downsides to proceeding with limited consent: potential later regret/complaint, moral injury to clinician, and that paralysis risk—while uncommon—is catastrophic and arguably material. Balance the other side by making delay meaningfully risky (worsening neurologic deficit, loss of surgical window, prolonged suffering) so full disclosure is not obviously best. Avoid relying on 'policy/state law permits' as a trump card; instead state both approaches are legally permissible but professionally contested.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove wording that implicitly favors limited disclosure. For example, replace “procedures are routine” with “procedures are commonly performed,” and replace “A longer consent discussion will likely delay the case and may lead the patient to refuse” with a more neutral description of competing concerns (e.g., “A longer consent discussion could delay same-day testing and may increase the patient’s anxiety, but may improve informed decision-making”). Avoid quoting “scary possibility”; rephrase clinically (e.g., “requests a more limited discussion of risks”).

Tighten by removing redundant affective descriptors (“exhausted, in pain”) unless they relate to decisional capacity; if capacity is relevant, state it explicitly (e.g., “appears to have capacity despite distress”).

balanced_difficulty: Reduce framing that makes Choice 2 look like a way to avoid refusal/delay and Choice 1 look like the ‘safer/more proper’ option. Rewrite to give each choice distinct, symmetric ethical costs: e.g., explicitly note that a full material-risk discussion may exacerbate panic and undermine the patient’s expressed preference not to hear details (risking distress and loss of trust), while limited disclosure risks later feelings of betrayal and medico-legal/relational harm if a complication occurs. Also neutralize language like ‘procedures are routine’ which downplays risk and can make limited disclosure seem more acceptable; instead state they are commonly performed but carry rare, serious harms. Add a sentence that the patient appears to understand the general nature/purpose and is decisional, but his anxiety is escalating, to keep both approaches defensible.

To force a true binary, explicitly rule out these intermediates: e.g., ‘Radiology has a single slot now; if missed, myelogram is delayed weeks, and the OR slot is released; no time for additional consults. Patient declines involving family and refuses sedation that would impair decision-making. The surgeon must either conduct a full material-risk review now or honor the patient’s request for limited disclosure and document it.’ Alternatively, change the binary to: (A) proceed today with myelogram under limited disclosure vs (B) do not proceed today and instead postpone invasive testing until a full consent discussion can occur.
no_guideline_override: This scenario may be largely resolved by legal/professional standards: if state law and hospital policy explicitly permit ‘patient-directed limited disclosure,’ then Choice 2 is legally sanctioned; if they require ‘material risk’ disclosure, Choice 2 is noncompliant. Either way, guidelines may override the dilemma. Fix by clarifying that standards are ambiguous or conflicting: e.g., hospital policy requires material-risk disclosure for surgery but allows patient-directed limitation for diagnostic procedures; state case law is unsettled about how far patients can waive disclosure for high-severity risks; risk management advises either approach is defensible if capacity and documentation are clear. Also add that a neurologic-injury risk, while rare, might be considered ‘material’ by some standards, making the permissibility contested rather than settled.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old has worsening low back pain with new leg numbness and weakness. MRI is nondiagnostic because of severe motion and metal artifact from prior hardware. CT suggests a possible large disk herniation, but the level is unclear. Radiology can perform a myelogram only this afternoon, and an OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if results show compressive disease. If today’s slot is missed, repeat testing and surgery will be delayed for weeks. The patient can describe the purpose, alternatives, and that he may choose to wait, and he appears to have decision-making capacity. He also becomes acutely panicked when specific complications are discussed and repeatedly asks you not to list “worst-case” outcomes, saying he wants to proceed today. You know myelography and decompression are commonly performed but can rarely cause permanent neurologic injury. Risk management advises that either a full material-risk discussion or a documented patient-limited disclosure is legally permissible, but clinicians disagree. You must obtain consent now.
data.choice_1: Describe all material risks, including rare paralysis, before proceeding with myelogram today.
data.choice_2: Honor his request for limited risk details and proceed with myelogram today.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old has worsening low back pain with new leg numbness and weakness. MRI is nondiagnostic because of severe motion and metal artifact from prior hardware. CT suggests a possible large disk herniation, but the level is unclear. Radiology can perform a myelogram only this afternoon, and an OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if results show compressive disease. If today’s slot is missed, repeat testing and surgery will be delayed for weeks. The patient can describe the purpose, alternatives, and that he may choose to wait, and he appears to have decision-making capacity. He also becomes acutely panicked when specific complications are discussed and repeatedly asks you not to list “worst-case” outcomes, saying he wants to proceed today. You know myelography and decompression are commonly performed but can rarely cause permanent neurologic injury. Risk management advises that either a full material-risk discussion or a documented patient-limited disclosure is legally permissible, but clinicians disagree. You must obtain consent now.

choice_1.choice: Describe all material risks, including rare paralysis, before proceeding with myelogram today.

choice_2.choice: Honor his request for limited risk details and proceed with myelogram today.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that delaying the myelogram/decompression by weeks carries a significant risk of irreversible neurologic deficit; and add that discussing rare paralysis predictably triggers panic such that he may refuse/postpone today’s study.

Add one clause making the harm tradeoff explicit—for example: note that a full risk discussion is likely to trigger a panic episode that could prevent completing today’s myelogram (causing weeks of delay and possible worsening neurologic deficits), and that limited disclosure risks the patient undergoing an invasive test without understanding a rare but catastrophic complication (e.g., paralysis) that could cause profound psychological harm and loss of trust if it occurs.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old has worsening low back pain with new leg numbness and weakness. MRI is nondiagnostic because of severe motion and metal artifact from prior hardware. CT suggests a possible large disk herniation, but the level is unclear. Radiology can perform a myelogram only this afternoon. An OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if results show compressive disease. If today’s slot is missed, repeat testing and surgery will be delayed for weeks, with a risk of progressive or irreversible neurologic deficit. The patient can describe the purpose, alternatives, and that he may choose to wait, and he appears to have decision-making capacity. He becomes acutely panicked when rare catastrophic complications are discussed, and this predictably makes him want to stop or postpone the study. He repeatedly asks you not to list “worst-case” outcomes and says he wants to proceed today. You know myelography and decompression are commonly performed but can rarely cause permanent neurologic injury, including paralysis. Risk management advises that either a full material-risk discussion or a documented patient-limited disclosure is legally permissible, but clinicians disagree. You must obtain consent now.

choice_1.choice: Describe all material risks, including rare paralysis, before proceeding with myelogram today.

choice_2.choice: Honor his request for limited risk details and proceed with myelogram today.

data.vignette: A 19-year-old has worsening low back pain with new leg numbness and weakness. MRI is nondiagnostic because of severe motion and metal artifact from prior hardware. CT suggests a possible large disk herniation, but the level is unclear. Radiology can perform a myelogram only this afternoon. An OR slot is reserved for tomorrow if results show compressive disease. If today’s slot is missed, repeat testing and surgery will be delayed for weeks, with a risk of progressive or irreversible neurologic deficit. The patient can describe the purpose, alternatives, and that he may choose to wait, and he appears to have decision-making capacity. He becomes acutely panicked when rare catastrophic complications are discussed, and this predictably makes him want to stop or postpone the study. He repeatedly asks you not to list “worst-case” outcomes and says he wants to proceed today. You know myelography and decompression are commonly performed but can rarely cause permanent neurologic injury, including paralysis. Risk management advises that either a full material-risk discussion or a documented patient-limited disclosure is legally permissible, but clinicians disagree. You must obtain consent now.

choice_1.choice: Describe all material risks, including rare paralysis, before proceeding with myelogram today.

choice_2.choice: Honor his request for limited risk details and proceed with myelogram today.
